articles.title: Super-sticky hydrogel is 10 times stronger than other glues underwater
articles.summary: Researchers analysed thousands of natural protein sequences and got assistance from AI in order to design a new hydrogel adhesive that can stay sticky underwater or even within a living body
articles.content:
Researchers analysed thousands of natural protein sequences and got assistance from AI in order to design a new hydrogel adhesive that can stay sticky underwater or even within a living body

Researchers tested a sticky hydrogel by using it to glue a rubber duck to a rock in the ocean Hao Guo, Hongguang Liao and Hailong Fan

A rubber duck that was stuck to a seaside rock for more than a year has proved the strength of a new sticky material. The adhesive could be used in deep-sea robots and repair work, or as surgical glue for medical procedures.

“We developed a super-adhesive hydrogel that works extremely well even underwater – something very few materials can achieve,” says Hailong Fan at Shenzhen University in China. Hydrogels are stretchy and soft materials.

Advertisement

Fan, then at Hokkaido University in Japan, and his colleagues analysed 24,000 sticky protein sequences from many different organisms to identify the stickiest combinations of amino acids, the building blocks of proteins. They used that information to create 180 different types of adhesive hydrogel. Then, they trained artificial intelligence models on the hydrogels’ material properties to predict even better recipes for super-sticky materials.

This process let the team develop a new class of versatile and sticky hydrogel. The material bonds to surfaces even when it has been unstuck and restuck multiple times or immersed in seawater, says Fan. It exceeded 1 megapascal of adhesion strength underwater – about 10 times stronger than most soft, sticky materials under the same conditions.

The research “demonstrates a paradigm shift in the way we can design high-performance soft materials”, says Zhao Qin at Syracuse University in New York state. He praised the team for identifying stickiness patterns in natural proteins and capturing them in the new material.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Weekly The best of New Scientist, including long-reads, culture, podcasts and news, each week. Sign up to newsletter

The most whimsical demonstration of the hydrogel’s sticky strength involved keeping that yellow rubber duck attached to the wave-soaked rock by the shore. In a more practical experiment, the hydrogel instantly sealed a leaking water pipe. This suggests it could help repair underwater structures or make flexible electronics and robotics water-resistant.

The material was also biocompatible, which the researchers proved by implanting it under the skin of mice. This could make it useful for biomedical applications, such as affixing implants or working as surgical glue.

The hydrogel’s stickiness is remarkable, says Qin, but he notes that the material must be relatively thick to perform well. He hopes to see it tested outside ideal experimental conditions, especially in real-world situations with rough, contaminated or moving surfaces.

The researchers have submitted a patent for the new material through Hokkaido University, where most of them work.

articles.personality_title: New super-strong hydrogel sticks underwater like never before
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long sought materials that can stick strongly underwater for uses like medical surgery or repairing machines in wet conditions. Traditional adhesives usually lose their stickiness when wet.

Using artificial intelligence (AI), they tested and improved 180 recipes to create a new hydrogel adhesive. This hydrogel stayed firmly stuck underwater, even holding a rubber duck on a rock in the ocean for over a year.

**Impact** – This hydrogel is about 10 times stronger than most soft adhesives in wet environments. It can be stuck and unstuck multiple times and still maintain its strength. **What's next step** – Researchers will likely explore real-world medical and industrial applications of this hydrogel. Testing in surgeries or underwater robotics could begin, aiming to replace less effective adhesives with this new material.

articles.personality_title: New imaging reveals simple movement patterns in deep-sea octopuses
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long been fascinated by how octopuses move, especially deep-sea species. Their flexible arms and unique crawling methods are complex, making them difficult to study in their natural environment.

**What happened** – Researchers used a new advanced imaging system called EyeRIS to observe deep-sea octopuses moving in their natural habitat. This technology allowed scientists to capture detailed light-field images of the octopuses' locomotion without disturbing them.

**Impact** – The study showed that deep-sea octopuses use surprisingly simplified crawling patterns despite their complex arms. This discovery challenges previous assumptions and offers clear models of movement. These insights can directly influence the design of soft robots, helping engineers build machines that move more efficiently and flexibly.

**What's next step** – The research team plans to apply this understanding to develop new robotic prototypes inspired by octopus movement. They also aim to study other behaviors using EyeRIS, expanding knowledge about deep-sea animals and improving bio-inspired technology.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Advanced imaging has uncovered simple yet effective octopus crawling patterns, opening new paths for bio-inspired robotic design.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs ont utilisé un nouveau système d'imagerie avancé appelé EyeRIS pour observer les pieuvres des grands fonds dans leur habitat naturel. Cette technologie a permis de capturer des images détaillées en champ lumineux de leur locomotion, sans les perturber.

**Impact** – L'étude a montré que ces pieuvres utilisent des schémas de déplacement étonnamment simples malgré la complexité de leurs bras. Cette découverte remet en question les idées reçues et offre des modèles clairs de mouvement. Ces résultats peuvent directement inspirer la conception de robots souples, aidant les ingénieurs à créer des machines plus efficaces et flexibles.

**Prochaine étape** – L'équipe de recherche prévoit d'appliquer ces connaissances pour développer de nouveaux prototypes robotiques inspirés par le mouvement des pieuvres. Ils souhaitent aussi étudier d'autres comportements grâce à EyeRIS, élargissant ainsi la connaissance des animaux des grands fonds et améliorant la technologie bio-inspirée.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Une imagerie avancée révèle des schémas simples de déplacement chez les pieuvres, ouvrant la voie à la conception de robots bio-inspirés.
